results.title: China's child
results.brief_description: Looks at population control measures implemented in China and economic and sociological implications of these. Couples must be over twenty-four years of age before marrying and are told when to conceive a child.

results.title: Eye of the octopus
results.creator_credit: James Siers, Judy Siers and Sierpinski Films
results.brief_description: Based on the true story of a 13 year old New Zealand boy who lives for a summer with the people of Kiribati, a remote Pacific island and learns their customs. He learns fishing, snorkelling, sailing, and survival techniques. Finally he must capture and kill an octopus in the customary manner.

results.title: Sonny Terry: shoutin' the blues
results.brief_description: Blind blues musician, Sonny Terry, performs a highly innovative piece on the harmonica. Filmed and recorded at the Broadway Motel, Oakland, California in 1969. (A useful compliment to ‘Chicago Blues’ title code: 507696)

results.title: Horse breaking
results.creator_credit: Agrifilm and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Depicts 72 year-old Kel Jeffrey applying his unique and humane method of gaining a horse’s confidence to the point where it will allow a saddle to be placed on its back and a person to ride it.

results.creator_credit: Colin South, Media World and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Aimed at students by encouraging them to participate in school councils and student representative councils, shows how to run meetings, procedures etc. and how students can be more effective in them. Part of the Participation and Equity Program.

results.title: Science: keeping you in the picture
results.creator_credit: Mark Laughlin, Gil Davidson and Victoria. Education Dept. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Trevor Lunn introduces Janet Hollands and Mark learmonth who provide an explanation of the process by which films and videos for science teachers were selected for inclusion in the Victorian Education Department’s Film and Video Collection. Includes excerpts from titles held in the collection.

results.title: Aloud / Bagatelle
results.creator_credit: Donald McWilliams, David Verrall, Douglas MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Canadian poet Earle Birney indulges his love of trains in this performance of his sound poem “To Swindon from London by Britrail”. Told in fluent “trainish”, he interprets the experience of excursions by rail. Imagination sparked by the rhythm of wheels and the clink of couplings, Birney hums, hisses and hoots his way through archival footage of vintage trains and English countryside. A must for language, animation and train buffs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald McWilliams, David Verrall, Douglas MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: All around us: radiation
results.creator_credit: Derek Cunningham and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description: Explains radiation, how it was discovered and how it is measured. Considers its applications and possible effects on health. Shows how radiation is used to our benefit in industry, medicine and research.

results.title: Who's running this school?
results.creator_credit: Jack Zalkalns, John Honey, Tasmania. Education Dept. and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Investigates some of the problems of school administration and management by focusing upon a dramatized presentation of one of the first days in the job of Annie Probert, a newly appointed school principal. Although she is not feeling well, her day looks fairly simple. However, as the days develops, unexpected problems intervene and Annie becomes a victim of the multiple expectations that are a universal hazard of the job. Useful in the areas of decision making, conflict resolution, time management and leadership.
